titlestmt.titleproper: A Finding Aid to the John McLaughlin papers, 1922-1979 in the Archives of American Art AAA.mclajohn
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Rihoko Ueno
titlestmt.sponsor: Funding for the processing of this collection was provided by the Frederick Hammersley Foundation.

note.p: This finding aid is associated with a MARC collection-level record. 210131

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-09-30T09:34-0400

did.abstract: The papers of Southern California art dealer and abstract painter John McLaughlin measure 3.3 linear feet and date from 1922 to 1979. The collection documents John McLaughlin's personal life and career through biographical material, correspondence, writings, Tamarind Lithography fellowship files, scattered personal business records, printed materials, artwork, and photographic material.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged as 8 series.

list.item: Series 1: Biographical Material, 1942-circa 1969 (0.1 linear feet; Box 1)
Series 3: Writings and Notes, circa 1934-1976 (0.7 linear feet; Box 1-2)
Series 4: Tamarind Lithography Fellowship Files, 1958-1970 (0.2 linear feet; Box 2)
Series 5: Personal Business Records, circa 1938-1974 (0.2 linear feet; Box 2)
Series 6: Printed Material, 1932-1979 (1.5 linear feet; Box 2-4)
Series 7: Artwork, circa 1958 (0.1 linear feet; Box 3-4)
Series 8: Photographic Material, 1922-1979 (0.2 linear feet; Box 3)

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: John Dwyer McLaughlin (1898-1976) was best known as one of the leading Los Angeles "hard-edge" geometric abstractionist painters and one of the artists featured in the seminal 1959 exhibition "Four Abstract Classicists" curated by Jules Langsner. McLaughlin was also a dealer of Japanese art prints.

McLaughlin was born and educated in Massachusetts. He served in the United States Navy during World War I from 1917-1921 and married Florence Emerson in 1928. McLaughlin began painting around 1932 with no formal training. In 1935, the couple moved to Japan and lived for several years before moving back to Boston, where they opened The Tokaido, Inc., a Japanese art print gallery. From this time up to the beginning of World War II, McLaughlin worked primarily as a print dealer, without huge success. During World War II, he served as a language intelligence officer in the Marines, primarily because of his knowledge of Japanese.

After the war, McLaughlin and his wife settled in Dana Point, California, where he began painting in earnest, gaining some early local successes. His painting, Hope Deferred was awarded first prize for oil painting in the 1948 San Diego Art Guild Annual. He became associated with the Felix Landau Gallery in Los Angeles and was one of four painters included in the historic 1959 "Four Abstract Classicists" exhibition at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art organized by critic Jules Langsner which also featured the work of Frederick Hammersley, Lorser Feitelson, and Karl Benjamin. The phrase "hard-edge painting" was first used in association with this exhibition as a description of a unique California style of geometric abstractionist painting.

Throughout the 1960s and 1970s McLaughlin exhibited widely and became a mentor for many younger Los Angeles area reductive painters. He was widely admired for his integrity and independent position regarding the art market. John McLaughlin died in Dana Point, California in 1976 at the age of 77.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Use of original papers requires an appointment and is limited to the Archives' Washington, D.C. Research Center. Contact Reference Services for more information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: The John McLaughlin papers are owned by the Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution. Literary rights as possessed by the donor have been dedicated to public use for research, study, and scholarship. The collection is subject to all copyright laws.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: Portions of the collection are available on 35 mm microfilm reels 1410-1413 at Archives of American Art offices, and through interlibrary loan. Researchers should note that the order of the microfilm does not reflect the current arrangement of the papers.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: The John McLaughlin papers were donated to the Archives of American Art in multiple installments. John McLaughlin donated material in 1973 and his widow Florence McLaughlin donated material in 1976. Additional papers were donated by the artist's nephew John McLaughlin in 1998 and 1999.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: John McLaughlin papers, 1922-1979, bulk 1936-1976. Archives of American Art, Smithsonian Institution.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: Portions of the collection were microfilmed on reels 1410-1413 soon after they were donated to the archives. The papers were fully processed according to current archival standards by Rihoko Ueno in 2014 with funding from the Frederick Hammersley Foundation.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: The Archives of American Art also holds an oral history interview of John D. McLaughlin conducted July 23, 1974, by Paul J. Karlstrom.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The papers of Southern California art dealer and abstract painter John McLaughlin measure 3.3 linear feet and date from 1922 to 1979. The collection documents John McLaughlin's personal life and career through biographical material, correspondence, writings, Tamarind Lithography fellowship files, scattered personal business records, printed materials, artwork, and photographic material.

Biographical material includes McLaughlin's military service records, art awards, and resumes. Correspondence is with friends, artists, museums, and galleries. Notable correspondents include Eugene Anderson, Karl Benjamin, Frederick Hammersley, Jules Langsner, Stanton Macdonald-Wright, Ad Reinhardt, and others. Writings and notes include several artist statements, lectures, notes, and lists and descriptions of paintings, some in the form of hand drawn sketches. Users will find McLaughlin's ideas about his work and aesthetics are referenced in much of the correspondence and writings. Some of the letters also document the evolution of the 1959 "Four Abstract Classicists" exhibition, particularly correspondence with Karl Benjamin, Peter Selz, and Jules Langsner. There are also writings about McLaughlin by others, including Jules Langsner. The Tamarind Lithography fellowship files consists of the letter of appointment, printed material, and profiles for fellow artists at the workshop.

Personal business records include assorted legal and financial papers, such as contracts with galleries, art loan agreements, consignment records, and art shipment expenses. There are business papers about McLaughlin's Japanese print gallery, The Tokaido, Inc. Printed material consists of exhibition catalogs for McLaughlin's shows at the Andre Emmerich Gallery, Felix Landau Gallery, a retrospective at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in 1968, and the seminal 1959 "Four Abstract Classicists" in Los Angeles, among others. Also found are exhibition announcements, news clippings, and press releases. Artwork includes a few paintings and collages. Photographs, negatives, and slides are of McLaughlin, including one portrait by John Waggaman), artwork, and exhibition installations. There is one album of photographs from a 1963 retrospective exhibition at the Pasadena Art Museum.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Biographical material includes military service records from World War II, scattered art fair awards, business cards, selected bibliographies, short artist biographies, and curriculum vitae.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically. Undated correspondence and McLaughlin's drafts of outgoing correspondence are grouped together toward the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Correspondence consists of personal and professional correspondence between John McLaughlin and friends, colleagues, fellow artists, museums directors, and galleries. Included are letters from the U.S. War Department during McLaughlin's military service, with collectors and galleries about selling his Japanese art prints, and letters about organizing and participating in exhibitions, including the 1959 "Four Abstract Classicists" exhibition. Many of the letters outline McLaughlin's thoughts on his work and aesthetics. Notable correspondents include Eugene Anderson, Karl Benjamin, Frederick Hammersley, Jules Langsner, Stanton Macdonald-Wright, Ad Reinhardt, and others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The materials in this series are grouped together by document type, such as artist statements, lectures, and notes, then organized chronologically within each grouping. Writings by others are grouped together at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Writings and notes include typescript and handwritten drafts of artist statements and lectures, in addition to notes and hand drawn lists and descriptions of paintings. The lists and descriptions of paintings are handwritten inventories and notes that include the medium and dimensions of paintings along with small sketches that have annotations about the colors. The bulk of the material in the series is comprised of McLaughlin's writings in addition to a few drafts written by others.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The materials in this series are grouped together by type, then organized chronologically within each grouping.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Tamarind Lithography fellowship files consists of the letter of appointment, assorted printed material such as brochures and press releases, and artist profiles and photographs for other recipients of the fellowship at the Tamarind Lithography Workshop.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by type of materials, then organized chronologically within each grouping.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Personal business records include assorted legal and financial papers. Legal material consists of a few estate papers and contracts agreeing to gallery representation. There are business papers, such as sales and inventory notes, concerning McLaughlin's Japanese print gallery, The Tokaido, Inc. Also included are art loan agreements, consignment records, and bills and receipts for art shipment expenses.

did.unittitle: The Tokaido Inventory and Sales Notes
The Tokaido Sales and Inventory Notes
The Tokaido Sales, Consignment, and Shipping Forms

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: This series is arranged by type of material, then organized chronologically within each grouping.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Printed material consists of exhibition catalogs for McLaughlin's group and solo shows, exhibition announcements, magazine and newspaper clippings, brochures, press releases, and miscellaneous materials.

scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 4, Folder 1.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Artwork consists of 1 folder with a few small paintings along with oversize collages that might have served as composition models for full-scale paintings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oversized material housed in Box 4, Folder 4.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The photographs are arranged by subject, then organized chronologically within each grouping.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Photographic material includes photographs and negatives, as well as a few slides. There is one album of photographs from a retrospective exhibition of McLaughlin's work at the Pasadena Art Museum. There are some personal photographs and portraits of McLaughlin, but the bulk of the series consists of black & white photographs of his paintings and exhibition installation.
